reasoning:
The critique targets a real component of the essay’s case for “fussiness”: that (i) many plausible views are effectively linear in resources (hence missing cosmic expansion forfeits most value) and (ii) linear-ish views should loom large under moral uncertainty. If that were undermined, the technical section’s scale-based argument would weaken. But it wouldn’t collapse the overall “no easy eutopia” position, which also relies heavily on non-scale-based fragility/multiplicative-factor arguments and on bounded-view fussiness via sensitivity to bads; so centrality is moderate, not high.

Argumentatively, the critique mostly flags contestability (“many reasonable views accept diminishing returns/person-affecting/rights”) rather than directly engaging the essay’s specific moves (e.g., why universal-bounded concavity becomes locally linear given tiny marginal influence; why unbounded/variance-normalised or pairwise comparisons may make unbounded views loom larger; why fat-tailed value-efficiency makes even non-scale mistakes costly). These points do provide some pressure—especially around the claim that linear separability deserves dominant credence—but they don’t substantially refute the essay’s defended conclusions, so strength is limited.

For Forethought’s agenda, this is moderately relevant: it engages Tier-2-ish premises about value scaling, linearity-in-practice, and how moral uncertainty affects which views dominate—issues that matter for prioritising flourishing vs survival and for how “narrow target” should be interpreted. However, it is somewhat generic and doesn’t surface a novel internal tension or new evidence, keeping relevance below high.
title: "Linearity assumptions require more justification"
